description.narrative: People in the regions of Racha-Lechkhumi - Kvemo Svaneti, Samegrelo-Zemo Svaneti, Guria and Kvemo Kartli benefit from stronger local self-government institutions for better economic development and employment generation

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).

description.narrative:
Indicators & Targets (2021):
Activity 1 (RRF Outcome 1) 1.1. # of new gender sensitive norms, policies and political processes developed and adopted by National and Municipal governments in the fields of LED as a result of project interventions (Target: at least additional 2) 1.2. # of LED-related additional competences delegated to municipalities as a result of project interventions (Target: 4) 1.3. % of increase in the share of municipal budget in consolidated GoG budget as a result of the improved fiscal transfer schemes and/or local tax income and private investments (Target: 13%)
Activity 2 (RRF Outcome 2) 2.1. # of municipalities with new gender sensitive and environmentally sustainable LED related measures incorporated in their Municipal Development Plans /bu¬dgets and implemented (Target: 23) 2.2. % of implemented new gender sensitive and environmentally sustainable LED related measures from municipal development plans/budgets (Target: 20%) 2.3. # of municipalities with new gender sensitive and environmentally sustainable LED related measures planned and implemented (Target: 8 municipalities) 2.4. % of increase in municipal budget allocations for new LED initiatives in project target municipalities (Target: 20%) 2.5. % of increase in central budget allocations for new LED initiatives in project target municipalities (Target: 20%) 2.6. Number of new businesses /extended businesses in project regions (Target: 500, at least 20% owned/run by women and/or youth) 2.7. Number of people employed by new businesses/extended businesses (Target: 1,000 (at least 30% women and/or youth)
Activity 3 (RRF Outcome 3): 3.1. # and % of citizens participation in targeted local decision-making and/or budget planning in 23 municipalities (disaggregated by women/ youth) of target 4 regions (Target: 12% in project target municipalities) 3.2. # of business benefiting from new local economic initiatives (disaggregated by ownership by women/ youth) (Target: 200) 3.3. % of populat

comment.narrative:
Indicators and Baselines (2018):
Activity 1 (RRF Outcome 1): 1.1. # of new gender sensitive norms, policies and political processes developed and adopted by National and Municipal governments in the fields of LED as a result of project interventions (Baseline: 0) 1.2. # of LED-related additional competences delegated to municipalities as a result of project interventions (Baseline: 0) 1.3. % of increase in the share of municipal budget in consolidated GoG budget as a result of the improved fiscal transfer schemes and/or local tax income and private investments (Baseline: 8.6%)
Activity 2 (RRF Outcome 2): 2.1. # of municipalities with new gender sensitive and environmentally sustainable LED related measures incorporated in their Municipal Development Plans/budgets and implemented (Baseline: 0) 2.2. % of implemented new gender sensitive and environmentally sustainable LED related measures from municipal development plans/budgets (Baseline: 0) 2.3. # of municipalities with new gender sensitive and environmentally sustainable LED related measures planned and implemented (Baseline: 0) 2.4. % of increase in municipal budget allocations for new LED initiatives in project target municipalities (Baseline: 0) 2.5. % of increase in central budget allocations for new LED initiatives in project target municipalities (Baseline: 0) 2.6. Number of new businesses /extended businesses in project regions (Baseline: 0) 2.7. Number of people employed by new businesses/extended businesses (Baseline: 0)
Activity 3 (RRF Outcome 3): 3.1. # and % of citizens participation in targeted local decision-making and/or budget planning in 23 municipalities (disaggregated by women/ youth) of target 4 regions (Baseline: 4,9% in target regions) 3.2. # of business benefiting from new local economic initiatives (disaggregated by ownership by women/ youth) (Baseline: 0) 3.3. % of population who believe decision-making is inclusive and responsive (disaggregated by women/ youth/ethnic minorities/vulner

2019 Targets:
Activity 1 (RRF Outcome 1) indicator targets: 1.1. # of new gender sensitive norms, policies and political processes developed and adopted by National and Municipal governments in the fields of LED as a result of project interventions: 2 1.2. # of LED-related additional competences delegated to municipalities as a result of project interventions: 1 1.3. % of increase in the share of municipal budget in consolidated GoG budget as a result of the improved fiscal transfer schemes and/or local tax income and private investments: n/a
Activity 2 (RRF Outcome 2) indicator targets: 2.1. # of municipalities with new gender sensitive and environmentally sustainable LED related measures incorporated in their Municipal Development Plans/budgets and implemented: 23 municipalities (for incorporated) 2.2. % of implemented new gender sensitive and environmentally sustainable LED related measures from municipal development plans/budgets: 0 2.3. # of municipalities with new gender sensitive and environmentally sustainable LED related measures planned and implemented: 0 2.4. % of increase in municipal budget allocations for new LED initiatives in project target municipalities: 0 2.5. % of increase in central budget allocations for new LED initiatives in project target municipalities: 0 2.6. Number of new businesses /extended businesses in project regions: n/a 2.7. Number of people employed by new businesses/extended businesses: n/a
Activity 3 (RRF Outcome 3) indicator targets: 3.1. # and % of citizens participation in targeted local decision-making and/or budget planning in 23 municipalities (disaggregated by women/ youth) of target 4 regions: n/a 3.2. # of business benefiting from new local economic initiatives (disaggregated by ownership by women/ youth): 2 3.3. % of population who believe decision-making is inclusive and responsive (disaggregated by women/ youth/ethnic minorities/vulnerable groups): n/a
RRF Output indicator targets: Output 1.1. 1.1.1. % of activities implemented from the action plan: 20% 1.1.2. % of increase in local budget revenues as a result of the implemented activities: n/a Output 1.2. 1.2.1. % of activities implemented from the action plan: 15% 1.2.2. % of increase in local budget revenues as a result of the implemented activities: n/a Output 1.3. 1.3.1. # of civil servants trained in LED related qualifications: 1.3.2. # of additional learning instruments introduced to support capacity development of local officials in LED: 1 1.3.3. # of local civil servants participating in planning and implementation of new LED initiatives: 50 Output 1.4. 1.4.1. Number of gender sensitive policy proposals supporting LED elaborated and advocated: 4 1.4.2. Number of advocacy activities including meetings, workshops, presentations and negotiations with relevant institutions: 20 1.4.3. Number of policies (gender sensitive) adopted as a result of advocacy activities: 2 Output 2.1. 2.1.1. # of municipalities with LED profiles: 0 2.1.2. # of municipalities with land use and zoning documents: 0 2.1.3. # of municipalities with focal points to provide guidance to potential investors promotion: 0 2.1.4. # of investors applying to focal point’s services: 0 2.1.5. # of business projects initiated in target municipalities as a result of provided support services: 0 Output 2.2. 2.2.2. Number of joint LED initiatives piloted: 2 Output 2.3. 2.3.1. Number of LED forums (Georgia- Armenia and Georgia- Azerbaijan) organized: 2 2.3.2. Number of joint activities developed as a result of LED forum: 0 Output 2.4. 2.4.1. Number of services with performance management instruments: 0 2.4.2. Number of municipalities with established performance management systems: 0 2.4.3. Number of municipalities replicating the performance management system: 0 2.4.4. % of local businesses reporting improvements in their activities as a result of performance management system: n/a Output 2.5. 2.5.1. Number of individuals applying to community centers: 0 2.5.2. Satisfaction rate of citizens using community centers services established: n/a Output 3.1. 3.1.1. % of population with understanding knowledge of their rights and roles to engage in LED in four regions: n/a 3.1.2. Number of local Civil Society Organizations (CSOs)/businesses (mostly SMEs)/Business Associations with strengthened capacities in sustainable LED: 10 3.1.3. Number of Civil Society Organizations engaged in participatory planning of sustainable LED initiatives: 5 3.1.4. Number of businesses engaged in participatory planning of sustainable LED initiatives: 0 Output 3.2. 3.2.1. Number of sustainable LED initiatives implemented by LSGs as a result of advocacy measures of Civil Advisory Councils and Business Associations: 4 3.2.2. Number of municipalities applying the guidelines to address citizen enquiries: 1 Output 3.3. 3.3.1. Number of consultation meetings with advisory councils held in project target municipalities: 0 3.3.2. Number of sustainable LED initiatives implemented by CSOs through small grants scheme: 10

2019 Results:
Activity 1 (RRF Outcome 1) indicator results: 1.1. # of new gender sensitive norms, policies and political processes developed and adopted by National and Municipal governments in the fields of LED as a result of project interventions: 3 policies/political processes developed and adopted: (i) Law on PPP was enacted on 1 July 2018, granting municipalities authority to engage in partnership with private sector; (ii) The Strategy for Decentralization (2020-2026) and its two-year Action Plan was finalized in consultation with a wide range of stakeholders and adopted by the GoG in December 2019; (iii) The Strategy for Development of High Mountain Settlements of Georgia (2019-2023) was finalized through public consultations and adopted by the GoG on 18 July 2019. 1.2. # of LED-related additional competences delegated to municipalities as a result of project interventions: 1 additional competency granted: amendment to the LSG Code on granting additional competences to the municipalities in the area of child protection adopted on 20 September 2019; 3 in progress (respective amendments elaborated and pending approval): 1.3. % of increase in the share of municipal budget in consolidated GoG budget as a result of the improved fiscal transfer schemes and/or local tax income and private investments: 9.8% (Source: MoF. Calculation is based on the 2019 planned budget data. Final budget data for 2019 will be available in March 2020, upon releasing the Budget Execution Report by the MoF)
Activity 2 (RRF Outcome 2) indicator results: 2.1. # of municipalities with new gender sensitive and environmentally sustainable LED related measures incorporated in their Municipal Development Plans/budgets and implemented: Municipal Development Documents (MDDs) along with their methodology are being updated for 39 municipalities of six regions of Georgia with a focus on LED and gender equality. 2.2. % of implemented new gender sensitive and environmentally sustainable LED related measures from municipal development plans/budgets: n/a - to be accomplished and measured upon updating MDDs 2.3. # of municipalities with new gender sensitive and environmentally sustainable LED related measures planned and implemented: Implemented in 1 municipality (in Tetritskaro), and in progress in 8 municipalities (Tsageri, Lanchkhuti, Chokhatauri, Zugdididi, Senaki, Martvili, Tsalenjikha, Poti) of 4 target regions. 2.4. % of increase in municipal budget allocations for new LED initiatives in project target municipalities: n/a - to be accomplished and measured upon updating MDDs 2.5. % of increase in central budget allocations for new LED initiatives in project target municipalities: n/a - to be accomplished and measured upon updating MDDs 2.6. Number of new businesses /extended businesses in project regions: 7,300 new businesses registered in four regions (2,454 (34%) owned/run by women): Racha-Lechkhumi-Kvemo Svaneti: 246 (44% owned/run by women); Samegrelo-Zemo Svaneti: 2,567 (42% owned/run by women); Kvemo Kartli: 3,605 (26% owned/run by women); Guria: 882 (39% owned/run by women) (Source: www.geostat.ge) 2.7. Number of people employed by new businesses/extended businesses: data on economic actors (enterprises, organizations), including the number of people employed by them, is confidential and cannot be shared (ref. to the Georgian Law on Official Statistics, Article 28)
Activity 3 (RRF Outcome 3) indicator results: 3.1. # and % of citizens participation in targeted local decision-making and/or budget planning in 23 municipalities (disaggregated by women/ youth) of target 4 regions: n/a - being measured through the survey on citizens’ satisfaction with public services in Georgia (to be accomplished by March 2020) 3.2. # of business benefiting from new local economic initiatives (disaggregated by ownership by women/ youth): 34 local SMEs and entrepreneurs benefitted from “Guria Tea Route” - a public-private cooperation project piloted in Ozurgeti Municipality 3.3. % of population who believe decision-making is inclusive and responsive (disaggregated by women/ youth/ethnic minorities/vulnerable groups): n/a - being measured through the survey on citizens’ satisfaction with public services in Georgia (to be accomplished by March 2020)
RRF Output indicator results: Output 1.1. 1.1.1. % of activities implemented from the action plan: 31% - 16 LED-related activities (i.e. 62% of all activities) were mapped in the last updated version of the Draft Decentralization Strategy Action Plan, of which implementation of 5 activities (31%) is being supported by FRLD 2 1.1.2. % of increase in local budget revenues as a result of the implemented activities: 11.5% increase in local budget revenues (according to the planned 2019 municipal budgets) Output 1.2. 1.2.1. % of activities implemented from the action plan: implementation of 18% of LED activities from the draft Action Plan of the Strategy for Development of High Mountain Settlements in progress 1.2.2. % of increase in local budget revenues as a result of the implemented activities: 6.9% decrease in the local budget revenues collected from local businesses (according to the planned 2019 municipal budget) due to transferring certain types of income taxes from local budget to the state budget as well as envisaged tax exemptions for local businesses Output 1.3. 1.3.1. # of civil servants trained in LED related qualifications: 306 national and local civil servants trained in LED related qualifications: 90 women (29.4%), 216 men (70.6%), 299 local/regional, 7 national 1.3.2. # of additional learning instruments introduced to support capacity development of local officials in LED: 2 learning instruments developed: (i) Guidebook on LED was developed by the project’s legal expert and printed to be disseminated among the target municipalities as a recommended learning resource on LED; (ii) Methodology on municipal development planning was developed by the Association of Young Economists of Georgia in consultation with a wide range of stakeholders, and finalized based on the feedback provided by the Administration of the GoG and MRDI 1.3.3. # of local civil servants participating in planning and implementation of new LED initiatives: 383 local civil servants (148/39% women, 235/61% men) involved in the planning teams officially set up in 34 municipalities to engage in the process of updating municipal development planning documents with a focus on LED Output 1.4. 1.4.1. Number of gender sensitive policy proposals supporting LED elaborated and advocated: 4 recommendations elaborated and advocated in partnership with National Association of Local Authorities of Georgia (NALAG) 1.4.2. Number of advocacy activities including meetings, workshops, presentations and negotiations with relevant institutions: 21 advocacy activities with relevant line ministries, the Parliament, and local authorities conducted in partnership with NALAG, including 14 accomplished in 2019 1.4.3. Number of policies (gender sensitive) adopted as a result of advocacy activities: 1 policy proposal on revision of state transfers (VAT sharing and PIT sharing) adopted and 2 (on property transfer and citizen participation) reflected in the Draft Decentralization Strategy as a result of advocacy efforts Output 2.1. 2.1.1. # of municipalities with LED profiles: in progress - draft Toolkit for preparation of Municipal Investment Profiles developed based on the analysis of international good practices. Support being provided to selected 8 municipalities to create investment profiles with guidelines and supplementary materials. 2.1.2. # of municipalities with land use and zoning documents: 1 in progress for Lanchkhuti municipality: preparation of land use and zoning document is in progress for Lanchkhuti municipality in partnership with the Department on Spatial Planning under MRDI. Consultation with the Department is underway to select additional target municipalities for elaboration of land use and zoning documents in line with the country’s spatial planning priorities. 2.1.3. # of municipalities with focal points to provide guidance to potential investors promotion: n/a - linked to Indicator 2.1.1. 2.1.4. # of investors applying to focal point’s services: n/a - linked to Indicator 2.1.3. 2.1.5. # of business projects initiated in target municipalities as a result of provided support services: n/a - linked to Indicators 2.1.1 – 2.1.4. Output 2.2. 2.2.2. Number of joint LED initiatives piloted: 1 joint LED initiative piloted in Ozurgeti Municipality; 8 initiatives in progress in Tsageri, Lanchkhuti, Chokhatauri, Zugdididi, Senaki, Martvili, Tsalenjikha, and Poti municipalities of 3 target regions Output 2.3. 2.3.1. Number of LED forums (Georgia- Armenia and Georgia- Azerbaijan) organized: 1 cross-border business and trade event organized in 2018. Negotiations are led with the potential local partner to organize cross-border LED forums in 2020. 2.3.2. Number of joint activities developed as a result of LED forum: n/a - linked to indicator 2.3.1. negotiations ongoing with the local partner Output 2.4. 2.4.1. Number of services with performance management instruments: development of PMS for 2 services in progress: assessment of service provision is conducted in 39 municipalities by the selected company to be followed by development of PMS for 23 municipalities (17 targeted by FRLD 2 and 6 by DGG) 2.4.2. Number of municipalities with established performance management systems: in progress for 8 municipalities (4 targeted by DGG and 4 by FRLD 2) - a consultancy company contracted to develop and pilot performance management systems for two municipal services 2.4.3. Number of municipalities replicating the performance management system: 0 - upon piloting in 8 municipalities, PMS will be replicated in additional 15 municipalities. 2.4.4. % of local businesses reporting improvements in their activities as a result of performance management system: n/a - linked to indicators 2.4.1 – 2.4.3 Output 2.5. 2.5.1. Number of individuals applying to community centers: Two CCs constructed, 1 functional: 2 Community Centers were constructed in Chrebalo (Ambrolauri Municipality) and Kachagani (Marneuli Municipality) in 2019. Kachagani CC was opened on 13 December 2019 and is functional, while opening of the CC in Chrebalo is scheduled in January 2020. The newly constructed CC in Kachagani offers about 20 public and private services to up to 20,000 local inhabitants from Kachagani and its 6 neighboring villages. Statistics on the number of individuals applying to the CCs will be available in 2020. Output 3.1. 3.1.1. % of population with understanding knowledge of their rights and roles to engage in LED in four regions: n/a - being measured through the survey on citizens’ satisfaction with public services in Georgia (to be accomplished by March 2020) 3.1.2. Number of local Civil Society Organizations (CSOs)/businesses (mostly SMEs)/Business Associations with strengthened capacities in sustainable LED: 69 local CSOs and SMEs (43 women/26 men) with strengthened capacities in sustainable LED (generating LED initiatives) in 4 target regions 3.1.3. Number of Civil Society Organizations engaged in participatory planning of sustainable LED initiatives: 12 local CSOs (including 9 led by women) got engaged in participatory planning of 7 LED initiatives funded through small grants scheme. 3.1.4. Number of businesses engaged in participatory planning of sustainable LED initiatives: 35 private sector representatives from 17 municipalities targeted by FRLD 2 and DGG involved in LED planning teams set up and facilitated by AYEG with the project support Output 3.2. 3.2.1. Number of sustainable LED initiatives implemented by LSGs as a result of advocacy measures of Civil Advisory Councils and Business Associations: 8 municipalities (Tsageri, Senaki, Martvili, Zugdidi, Tsalenjikha, Poti, Lanchkhuti and Chokhatauri) provided with direct funding to implement sustainable LED initiatives involving Civil Advisory Councils and/or BAs. 3.2.2. Number of municipalities applying the guidelines to address citizen enquiries: In progress in Marneuli municipality – in 2019, front office was established in the City Hall to provide consultations and effectively direct citizen’s inquiries. Draft guidelines elaborated and will be finalized in 2020. Output 3.3. 3.3.1. Number of consultation meetings with advisory councils held in project target municipalities: planned in 2020 - meetings with Advisory Councils will be facilitated by the CSOs provided with grants by FRLD 2 3.3.2. Number of sustainable LED initiatives implemented by CSOs through small grants scheme: 7 participatory LED initiatives (including 5 led by women) were funded through small grants scheme in 2019 and will be implemented in 23 municipalities of four target regions during 2020-2021.

2020 Targets:
Activity 1 (RRF Outcome 1) indicator targets: 1.1. # of new gender sensitive norms, policies and political processes developed and adopted by National and Municipal governments in the fields of LED as a result of project interventions: 2 1.2. # of LED-related additional competences delegated to municipalities as a result of project interventions: 1.3. % of increase in the share of municipal budget in consolidated GoG budget as a result of the improved fiscal transfer schemes and/or local tax income and private investments: 11%
Activity 2 (RRF Outcome 2) indicator targets: 2.1. # of municipalities with new gender sensitive and environmentally sustainable LED related measures incorporated in their Municipal Development Plans/budgets and implemented: 23 municipalities of 4 target regions 2.2. % of implemented new gender sensitive and environmentally sustainable LED related measures from municipal development plans/budgets: 20% 2.3. # of municipalities with new gender sensitive and environmentally sustainable LED related measures planned and implemented: 5 2.4. % of increase in municipal budget allocations for new LED initiatives in project target municipalities: 20% 2.5. % of increase in central budget allocations for new LED initiatives in project target municipalities: 20% 2.6. Number of new businesses /extended businesses in project regions: 200 2.7. Number of people employed by new businesses/extended businesses: 400
Activity 3 (RRF Outcome 3) indicator targets: 3.1. # and % of citizens participation in targeted local decision-making and/or budget planning in 23 municipalities (disaggregated by women/ youth) of target 4 regions: 12% 3.2. # of business benefiting from new local economic initiatives (disaggregated by ownership by women/ youth): 2 00 3.3. % of population who believe decision-making is inclusive and responsive (disaggregated by women/ youth/ethnic minorities/vulnerable groups): TBD in consultation with donors
RRF Output indicator targets: Output 1.1. 1.1.1. % of activities implemented from the action plan: 40% 1.1.2. % of increase in local budget revenues as a result of the implemented activities: 30% Output 1.2. 1.2.1. % of activities implemented from the action plan: 30% 1.2.2. % of increase in local budget revenues as a result of the implemented activities: 12% Output 1.3. 1.3.1. # of civil servants trained in LED related qualifications: 300 1.3.2. # of additional learning instruments introduced to support capacity development of local officials in LED: 5 1.3.3. # of local civil servants participating in planning and implementation of new LED initiatives: 200 Output 1.4. 1.4.1. Number of gender sensitive policy proposals supporting LED elaborated and advocated: 4 1.4.2. Number of advocacy activities including meetings, workshops, presentations and negotiations with relevant institutions: 20 1.4.3. Number of policies (gender sensitive) adopted as a result of advocacy activities: 2 Output 2.1. 2.1.1. # of municipalities with LED profiles: 8 2.1.2. # of municipalities with land use and zoning documents: 2 2.1.3. # of municipalities with focal points to provide guidance to potential investors promotion: 8 2.1.4. # of investors applying to focal point’s services: 0 2.1.5. # of business projects initiated in target municipalities as a result of provided support services: 0 Output 2.2. 2.2.2. Number of joint LED initiatives piloted: 4 Output 2.3. 2.3.1. Number of LED forums (Georgia- Armenia and Georgia- Azerbaijan) organized: 2 2.3.2. Number of joint activities developed as a result of LED forum: 2 Output 2.4. 2.4.1. Number of services with performance management instruments: 1 2.4.2. Number of municipalities with established performance management systems: 6 2.4.3. Number of municipalities replicating the performance management system: 11 2.4.4. % of local businesses reporting improvements in their activities as a result of performance management system: 0 Output 2.5. 2.5.1. Number of individuals applying to community centers: 2,000 2.5.2. Satisfaction rate of citizens using community centers services established: 60% Output 3.1. 3.1.1. % of population with understanding knowledge of their rights and roles to engage in LED in four regions: 15% 3.1.2. Number of local Civil Society Organizations (CSOs)/businesses (mostly SMEs)/Business Associations with strengthened capacities in sustainable LED: 20 3.1.3. Number of Civil Society Organizations engaged in participatory planning of sustainable LED initiatives: 25 3.1.4. Number of businesses engaged in participatory planning of sustainable LED initiatives: 15 Output 3.2. 3.2.1. Number of sustainable LED initiatives implemented by LSGs as a result of advocacy measures of Civil Advisory Councils and Business Associations: 5 3.2.2. Number of municipalities applying the guidelines to address citizen enquiries: 1 Output 3.3. 3.3.1. Number of consultation meetings with advisory councils held in project target municipalities: 30 3.3.2. Number of sustainable LED initiatives implemented by CSOs through small grants scheme: 7

2020 Results:
Activity 1 (RRF Outcome 1): 1.1. # of new gender sensitive norms, policies and political processes developed and adopted by National and Municipal governments in the fields of LED as a result of project interventions: 3 policies/political processes developed and adopted: (i) Law on PPP enacted on 1 July 2018, granting municipalities authority to engage in partnership with private sector (reflected in 2018 Annual Report); (ii) The Strategy for Decentralization (2020-2025) and its two-year Action Plan adopted by the GoG on 31 December 2019 (reflected in 2019 Annual Report); (iii) The Strategy for Development of High Mountain Settlements of Georgia (2019-2023) adopted by the GoG on 18 July 2019. 1.2. # of LED-related additional competences delegated to municipalities as a result of project interventions: 4 additional competencies granted, 1 in progress. 1.3. % of increase in the share of municipal budget in consolidated GoG budget as a result of the improved fiscal transfer schemes and/or local tax income and private investments: 11.1% (Source: MoF. Calculation is based on the 2019 actual budget data. (Note: the state budget in the given indicator implies consolidated GoG budget, which consists of the state budget plus municipal budgets).
Activity 2 (RRF Outcome 2): 2.1. # of municipalities with new gender sensitive and environmentally sustainable LED related measures incorporated in their Municipal Development Plans/budgets and implemented: 37 municipalities of 6 regions with LED measures incorporated in MDDs and budgets, 19 municipalities (including 10 targeted by FRLD 2) with adopted MDDs 2.2. % of implemented new gender sensitive and environmentally sustainable LED related measures from municipal development plans/budgets: 81%: in 23 target municipalities, 256 LED measures are incorporated in MDDs, for which funds were allocated in 2020 municipal budgets for 208 measures (Final budgetary data will be available upon releasing the budget execution reports in March 2021) 2.3. # of municipalities with new gender sensitive and environmentally sustainable LED related measures planned and implemented: 5 municipalities with LED-related measures planned and implemented: Tetritskaro (reported in 2019); Chokhatauri, Zugdidi, Senaki, and Poti (2020 progress), covering 4 target regions. In progress in 8 additional municipalities: Tsageri, Tsalenjikha, Lanchkhuti, Martvili, Oni, Ozurgeti, Mestia, Bolnisi 2.4. % of increase in municipal budget allocations for new LED initiatives in project target municipalities: 67% (In 23 target municipalities, municipal budget allocations for LED initiatives was 154,8 million GEL in 2017 and 258,5 million GEL in 2019. Calculation is made based on the following assumption: all new capital expenditures are municipal budget allocations for new LED initiatives, as well as current expenditures that were directly reflected and described in the budget as LED initiative) 2.5. % of increase in central budget allocations for new LED initiatives in project target municipalities: 140% (In 23 target municipalities, central budget allocations for LED initiatives was 115 million GEL in 2017 and 276,1 million GEL in 2019. The data source for measuring this indicator include: the Roads Department of Georgia, MDF, United Water Supply Company, RDF, Highland Regions Development Fund, Ministry of Education and Science, Culture and Sport of Georgia, Ministry of Justice of Georgia, MoESD and the Offices of Regional Administrations (Governors). The calculation is made based on the following assumption: all new capital expenditures are central budget allocations for new LED initiatives.) 2.6. Number of new businesses /extended businesses in project regions: 21,275 new businesses registered in four regions (4,820 (23%) owned/run by women) (The data was officially obtained from the GeoStat in July 2020 and correspond to the number of businesses registered in 2019. 2020 updated statistics will be available in May 2021) 2.7. Number of people employed by new businesses/extended businesses: 67,290 people (58% women) became unemployed in four regions (Number of people employed through FRLD 2 efforts will be reported by the next reporting period the presented data is provided by GeoStat and illustrates the labour market figures in the targeted regions as of 2019. 2020 updated statistics will be available in May 2021)
Activity 3 (RRF Outcome 3): 3.1. # and % of citizens participation in targeted local decision-making and/or budget planning in 23 municipalities (disaggregated by women/ youth) of target 4 regions: For 4 target regions: 14.6% (12.4% women, 17.5% youth) (Participation in decision-making about the community problems in the neighborhood/district and/or in local budget planning). Source: UNDP FRLD 2019 Survey on Citizens’ Satisfaction with Public Services in Georgia. 3.2. # of business benefiting from new local economic initiatives (disaggregated by ownership by women/ youth): 262 local SMEs and entrepreneurs (40 owned by women, 15 owned by youth) benefitting 3.3. % of population who believe decision-making is inclusive and responsive (disaggregated by women/ youth/ethnic minorities/vulnerable groups): 46% in 4 target regions (43% women, 49% youth, 29% ethnic minorities, 52% vulnerable groups)
RRF Outputs: Output 1.1. 1.1.1. % of activities implemented from the action plan: 63% of LED-related activities implemented with FRLD 2/DGG support 1.1.2. % of increase in local budget revenues as a result of the implemented activities: 32% increase in local budget revenues according to the planned 2020 municipal budgets (Source: 2019 planned municipal budgets https://mof.ge/5245) Output 1.2. 1.2.1. % of activities implemented from the action plan: 40.9% of LED-related activities implemented; 59.1% in progress 1.2.2. % of increase in local budget revenues as a result of the implemented activities: 1.4% decrease Output 1.3. 1.3.1. # of civil servants trained in LED related qualifications: 343 national and local civil servants trained (cumulative for 2017-2020): 105 (31%) women, 238 (69%) men; 337 local/regional, 6 national 1.3.2. # of additional learning instruments introduced to support capacity development of local officials in LED: 12 learning instruments on LED developed and available for use by the municipalities: (i) a Guidebook on LED for municipalities developed by the project’s legal expert (reported in 2019); (ii) MDD Methodology developed in partnership with the Association of Young Economists of Georgia (pending GoG approval) (reported in 2019); (iii) 10 training modules on LED developed and piloted by CTC – a local company contracted by FRLD 2. 1.3.3. # of local civil servants participating in planning and implementation of new LED initiatives: 383 local civil servants (148/39% women, 235/61% men) involved in the planning teams officially set up in 34 municipalities (23 target municipalities of FRLD 2 and 11 DGG municipalities) to engage in the process of updating municipal development planning documents with a focus on LED Output 1.4. 1.4.1. Number of gender sensitive policy proposals supporting LED elaborated and advocated: 7 recommendations elaborated and advocated 1.4.2. Number of advocacy activities including meetings, workshops, presentations and negotiations with relevant institutions: 35 advocacy activities (meetings, workshops, presentations, negotiations) with relevant line ministries, the Parliament, and local authorities. 1.4.3. Number of policies (gender sensitive) adopted as a result of advocacy activities: 3 adopted (i) On sharing PIT (reflected in Activity 2.1.4 of the Draft Decentralization Strategy); (ii) On property transfer (reflected in Activity 2.1.6 of the Strategy); (iii) On citizen participation mechanisms, aimed at increasing engagement of active citizens in local decision-making and budget planning (reflected in Activity 3.3.1 of Draft Strategy). Output 2.1. 2.1.1. # of municipalities with LED profiles: Municipal Investment Profiles developed for 8 municipalities (Zugdidi and Mestia municipalities in Samegrelo-Zemo Svaneti region, Ambrolauri and Tsageri municipalities in Racha-Lechkhumi-Kvemo Svaneti region, Ozurgeti and Chokhatauri municipalities in Guria region, Rustavi and Bolnisi municipalities in Kvemo Kartli region) 2.1.2. # of municipalities with land use and zoning documents: In progress for 2 municipalities (Lanchkhuti Municipality (Grigoleti) and Ozurgeti Municipality (Gomi Settlement)) 2.1.3. # of municipalities with focal points to provide guidance to potential investors promotion: 8 municipalities (Ambrolauri, Tsageri, Mestia, Zugdidi, Ozurgeti, Chokhatauri, Bolnisi, Rustavi) with 16 focal points (2 per municipality) 2.1.4. # of investors applying to focal point’s services: No progress to date due to the socio-economic distress caused by the Covid-19 pandemic 2.1.5. # of business projects initiated in target municipalities as a result of provided support services: No progress to date due to the socio-economic distress caused by the Covid-19 pandemic Output 2.2. 2.2.2. Number of joint LED initiatives piloted: 10 LED initiatives piloted - 2 accomplished, 8 in progress: 7 joint LED initiative piloted in Ozurgeti (two initiatives - „Guria Tea Route” and “Info Centre on Wheels”), Tetritskaro (reported in 2019); Chokhatauri, Zugdidi, Senaki, and Poti (2020 progress) municipalities, covering 4 target regions. In progress in 8 additional municipalities: Tsageri, Tsalenjikha, Lanchkhuti, Martvili, Oni, Ozurgeti, Mestia, Bolnisi Output 2.3. 2.3.1. Number of LED forums (Georgia- Armenia and Georgia- Azerbaijan) organized: 2 forums organized in partnership with NALAG - 1 LED forum (Armenian-Georgian) organized in February 2020; 1 LED forum (Azerbaijani-Georgian) organized in July 2020. 2.3.2. Number of joint activities developed as a result of LED forum: 3 joint activities implemented: 1. Research exploring the trade potential of the municipalities along the Georgia-Azerbaijan border in Marneuli Red Bridge conducted jointly with the regional development association TAMA (Az NGO) 2. A network of Azerbaijani women farmers created 3. A catalogue of products of the women farmers residing in cross-border villages created by AzeriWomen (FRLD 2 small grant recipient CSO) Output 2.4. 2.4.1. Number of services with performance management instruments: PMS methodology and the analytical module for the e-tool was developed for two municipal services – street cleaning and municipal waste management in partnership with the local consultancy company - Policy and Management Consulting Group (PMCG). This encompasses development of the criteria for assessing the effectiveness of service delivery and preparation of the concept on e-platform, aimed at creating the opportunity for effective management and monitoring of the noted services at the municipal level. 2.4.2. Number of municipalities with established performance management systems: In progress: PMCG developed a recommendation on the selection of eight municipalities for piloting PMS. Upon reaching agreement on the pilot municipalities with MRDI, implementation of PMS will commence. 2.4.3. Number of municipalities replicating the performance management system: In progress: a recommendation on the selection of sixteen municipalities for the replication of PMS was developed by PMCG and awaiting approval. 2.4.4. % of local businesses reporting improvements in their activities as a result of performance management system: 0 (to be tracked upon introducing PMS in target municipalities) Output 2.5. 2.5.1. Number of individuals applying to community centers: 1,252 local citizens (37% women) applied to the two Community Centers opened in December 2019 and January 2020: 878 people applied to the services of PSDA in Kachagani CC, while Chrebalo CC served 374 citizens. 2.5.2. Satisfaction rate of citizens using community centers services established: Satisfaction of citizens with the services received at: Kachagani CC: 99%; Chrebalo CC: 100% Output 3.1. 3.1.1. % of population with understanding knowledge of their rights and roles to engage in LED in four regions: For 4 target regions: 13.3% (11.4% women, 19% youth). Source: the Survey on Citizens’ Satisfaction with Public Services in Georgia administered in 2019. 3.1.2. Number of local Civil Society Organizations (CSOs)/businesses (mostly SMEs)/Business Associations with strengthened capacities in sustainable LED: 69 local CSOs and SMEs (43 women/26 men/7 youth) with strengthened capacities in sustainable LED (generating LED initiatives) in 4 target regions 3.1.3. Number of Civil Society Organizations engaged in participatory planning of sustainable LED initiatives: 33 local CSOs engaged in participatory planning of sustainable LED initiatives (14 led by women, 2 led by youth) 3.1.4. Number of businesses engaged in participatory planning of sustainable LED initiatives: 39 private sector representatives (10 owned by women; 4 – by youth) from 24 municipalities targeted by FRLD 2 and DGG involved in LED planning teams set up and facilitated by AYEG with the project support Output 3.2. 3.2.1. Number of sustainable LED initiatives implemented by LSGs as a result of advocacy measures of Civil Advisory Councils and Business Associations: 5 municipalities with LED-related measures planned and implemented: Tetritskaro (reported in 2019); Chokhatauri, Zugdidi, Senaki, and Poti (2020 progress), covering 4 target regions. In progress in 8 additional municipalities: Tsageri, Tsalenjikha, Lanchkhuti, Martvili, Oni, Ozurgeti, Mestia, Bolnisi. All projects envisage engagement of Civil Advisory Councils and/or BAs. 3.2.2. The process was delayed due to Covid-19 and management changes in MSDA. Output 3.3. 3.3.1. Number of consultation meetings with advisory councils held in project target municipalities: 35 consultation meetings conducted with advisory councils in four target regions by the grant recipient CSOs 3.3.2. Number of sustainable LED initiatives implemented by CSOs through small grants scheme: 14 participatory LED initiatives implemented (7) /launched (7) (9 led by women, 1 led by youth)

2021 Results:
Activity 1 (RRF Outcome 1): 1.1. # of new gender sensitive norms, policies and political processes developed and adopted by National and Municipal governments in the fields of LED as a result of project interventions: 3 policies/political processes developed and adopted: (i) Law on PPP enacted on 1 July 2018, granting municipalities authority to engage in partnership with private sector (reflected in 2018 Annual Report); (ii) The Strategy for Decentralization (2020-2025) and its two-year Action Plan adopted by the GoG on 31 December 2019 (reflected in 2019 Annual Report); (iii) The Strategy for Development of High Mountain Settlements of Georgia (2019-2023) adopted by the GoG on 18 July 2019. 1.2. # of LED-related additional competences delegated to municipalities as a result of project interventions: 4 additional competencies granted, 1 in progress. 1.3. % of increase in the share of municipal budget (excluding Tbilisi) in consolidated GoG budget as a result of the improved fiscal transfer schemes and/or local tax income and private investments: 9.2% (Source: MoF. Calculation is based on the 2020 actual budget data. (Note: the state budget in the given indicator implies consolidated GoG budget, which consists of the state budget plus municipal budgets).
Activity 2 (RRF Outcome 2): 2.1. # of municipalities with new gender sensitive and environmentally sustainable LED related measures incorporated in their Municipal Development Plans/budgets and implemented: 37 municipalities of 6 regions with LED measures incorporated in MDDs and budgets. As of 2021, 24 municipalities (including 13 targeted by FRLD 2) have approved MDDs by respective Municipal Councils. Gender mainstreaming of MDDs was conducted by the Municipal Service Providers Association of Georgia (MSPA) in 14 municipalities (7 FRDL 2, 7 DGG).
2.2. % of implemented new gender sensitive and environmentally sustainable LED related measures from municipal development plans/budgets: 81%: in 23 target municipalities, 256 LED measures are incorporated in MDDs, for which funds were allocated in 2020 municipal budgets for 208 measures 2.3. # of municipalities with new gender sensitive and environmentally sustainable LED related measures planned and implemented: 10 municipalities with LED-related measures planned and implemented: Tetritskaro (reported in 2019); Chokhatauri, Zugdidi, Senaki, and Poti (reported in 2020); Martvili, Tetritskaro, Lanchkuti, Tsageri, Bolnisi (2021 progress) covering 4 target regions. In progress in 10 additional municipalities: Tsageri, Ambrolauri, Oni, Lentekhi, Ozurgeti, Chokhatauri, Mestia, Abasha, Senaki, Rustavi. indicator has been removed based on mutual agreement with project donors.
2.4. % of increase in municipal budget allocations for new LED initiatives in project target municipalities: 83.5% (based on 2020 planned budgets)
2.5. % of increase in central budget allocations for new LED initiatives in project target municipalities: 500% (based on 2020 planned budgets)
2.6. Number of new businesses /extended businesses in project regions: indicator has been removed based on mutual agreement with project donors.
2.7. Number of people employed by new businesses/extended businesses: indicator has been removed based on mutual agreement with project donors.
Activity 3 (RRF Outcome 3): 3.1. # and % of citizens participation in targeted local decision-making and/or budget planning in 23 municipalities (disaggregated by women/ youth) of target 4 regions: For 4 target regions: 10.2% (10.0% women, 5.9% youth) (Participation in decision-making about the community problems in the neighborhood/district and/or in local budget planning). Source: UNDP FRLD 2021 Survey on Citizens’ Satisfaction with Public Services in Georgia. 3.2. # of business benefiting from new local economic initiatives (disaggregated by ownership by women/ youth): 324 local SMEs and entrepreneurs (53 owned by women, 18 owned by youth) benefitting 3.3. % of population who believe decision-making is inclusive and responsive (disaggregated by women/ youth/ethnic minorities/vulnerable groups): Nationwide: 50.9% (51.6% women, 49.4 youth, 41.0% ethnic minorities, 60.3% vulnerable groups) Four target regions: 56.4% (53.5% women, 54.3% youth, 35.9% ethnic minorities, 62.1% vulnerable groups)
RRF Outputs: Output 1.1. 1.1.1. % of activities implemented from the action plan: 63% of LED-related activities from the Decentralization Strategy Action Plan (AP) implemented with FRLD 2/DGG support, while by 2021, 71,4% of all activities were completed.
1.1.2. % of increase in local budget revenues as a result of the implemented activities: 20,7% increase in local budget revenues (according to the planned 2021 municipal budgets ); Actual data for 2019 was 39,3%. As expected, the COVID Pandemic has affected the municipalitys revenues and the planned figures for 2021 have decreased compared to 2019.
Output 1.2.
1.2.1. % of activities implemented from the action plan: 40.9% of LED-related activities implemented; 59.1% in progress 1.2.2. % of increase in local budget revenues as a result of the implemented activities: 7.5% decrease in the local budget revenues collected from local businesses (according to the planned 2021 municipal budget). In the current circumstances, caused by COVID Pandemic increase in the local budget revenues through local taxes is less likely.
Output 1.3. 1.3.1. # of civil servants trained in LED related qualifications: 524 national and local civil servants trained (cumulative for 2017-2021): 221 (42%) women, 303 (58%) men 518 local/regional, 6 national
1.3.2. # of additional learning instruments introduced to support capacity development of local officials in LED: 12 learning instruments on LED developed and available for use by the municipalities (2 in 2019, 10 in 2020, 1 in 2021): (i) Guidebook on LED for municipalities was developed by the project’s legal expert as a recommended learning resource on LED (reported in 2019) (ii) MDD Methodology developed in partnership with the Association of Young Economists of Georgia in consultation with a wide range of stakeholders (pending GoG approval) (reported in 2019); (iii) 10 training modules on LED developed and piloted by the local company – the Centre for Training and Consultancy (CTC) - contracted by UNDP for designing a model for capacity development system.
1.3.3. # of local civil servants participating in planning and implementation of new LED initiatives: 383 local civil servants (148/39% women, 235/61% men) involved in the planning teams officially set up in 34 municipalities (23 target municipalities of FRLD 2 and 11 DGG municipalities) to engage in the process of updating municipal development planning documents with a focus on LED
Output 1.4. 1.4.1. Number of gender sensitive policy proposals supporting LED elaborated and advocated: 7 recommendations elaborated and advocated 1.4.2. Number of advocacy activities including meetings, workshops, presentations and negotiations with relevant institutions: 35 advocacy activities (meetings, workshops, presentations, negotiations) with relevant line ministries, the Parliament, and local authorities. 1.4.3. Number of policies (gender sensitive) adopted as a result of advocacy activities: 3 adopted (i) On sharing PIT (reflected in Activity 2.1.4 of the Draft Decentralization Strategy); (ii) On property transfer (reflected in Activity 2.1.6 of the Strategy); (iii) On citizen participation mechanisms, aimed at increasing engagement of active citizens in local decision-making and budget planning (reflected in Activity 3.3.1 of Draft Strategy). Output 2.1. 2.1.1. # of municipalities with LED profiles: Municipal Investment Profiles developed for 11 municipalities (Zugdidi, Senaki and Mestia municipalities in Samegrelo-Zemo Svaneti region, Ambrolauri, Oni and Tsageri municipalities in Racha-Lechkhumi-Kvemo Svaneti region, Ozurgeti, Lanchkhuti and Chokhatauri municipalities in Guria region, Rustavi and Bolnisi municipalities in Kvemo Kartli region) 2.1.2. # of municipalities with land use and zoning documents: 3. One in progress for Ozurgeti municipality (Gomi Mountain); Completed for 2 municipalities (Lanchkhuti Municipality (Grigoleti) and Ambrolauri Municipality (Nikortsminda). 2.1.3. # of municipalities with focal points to provide guidance to potential investors promotion: 11 municipalities (Ambrolauri, Tsageri, Mestia, Zugdidi, Ozurgeti, Chokhatauri, Bolnisi, Rustavi, Senaki, Oni, Lanchkhuti) with 19 focal points
2.1.4. # of investors applying to focal point’s services: 67 potential investors/local business representatives applied to focal points for the following services: construction permits, co-funding opportunities, information about leasing and available agricultural land plots, information about local fees and taxes, additional information about project proposals provided in municipal investment profile etc.
In addition, 3 regional investment-entrepreneurial forums were conducted, in Guria, Racha-Lechkhumi-Kvemo Svaneti region and Samegrelo Zemo Svaneti region with over 200 attendees.
2.1.5. # of business projects initiated in target municipalities as a result of provided support services: No progress to date due to the socio-economic distress caused by the Covid-19 pandemic
